properties.Notes: Restaurant frequented by gay men and lesbians, near Joanna’s.  “Bright, fluorescent lights and campy poodle figurines…late night eggs and coffee”—Peter Jefts.  Also known as Millie and Lou’s Restaurant.  1970 International Guild Guide notes “G-crowd after-hours only.”

properties.Name: Saunders Health Center
properties.Notes: Reportedly a gay-friendly health club which started as a Turkish bath in 1954.

properties.Name: Silver Fox
properties.Notes: Owner John Dracopoulos

properties.Name: Skyline Collective (Skyline Faggots)
properties.Notes: Off-shoot of the nearby GLF house.  A banner over the door read “Skyline Faggots.”  (See entry for GLF House.)

properties.Name: Terminal Hotel
properties.Notes: Hotel rooms above the Naples Café rented by the hour for 'short term assignations'.   Used by gay sex workers.  Owner:  Nick Papanicolas

properties.Name: Village Books
properties.Notes: Adult bookstore owned by Guild Press/H Lynn Womack.  The Village Books was originally a New York adult bookstore taken over by Womack and extended around the mid-Atlantic.  In the Norfolk VA area there were an additional five Village Books stores.  (See also entries for Guild Press; Mark I; Mark II.)

properties.Name: Village Books
properties.Notes: Another in the chain of adult bookstores run by the Guild Press.

properties.Name: Village Books
properties.Notes: Third in the chain of Guild Press adult bookstores

properties.Name: All Souls Unitarian Church
properties.Notes: All Souls has been in the forefront of support for civil rights, including GLBT civil rights.  Its meeting spaces have frequently been used by gay community organizations.  In 1970, All Souls was the site of the Black Panthers’ Peoples Revolutionary Constitutional Convention, an event staged with the strong support of DC’s Gay Liberation Front.  In 1970, the Homophile Social League met here as well as the Community Church organized by Rev. Paul Breton, which later became the Metropolitan Community Church of DC.  (See listing for MCC.)

properties.Name: The Community Building
properties.Notes: Connected to counterculture and anti-war activity.  Among many groups to meet there (Black Panthers Defense Committee; Washington Area Free University, etc.), it housed off our backs, the Gay Switchboard, the Blade, and the original Lambda Rising.  “We used to joke that the building was only held together by all the wiretaps the FBI had placed there”—Deacon Maccubbin.  The last gay-specific organizations moved out in the 1980s; as of 2012, the building is advertised as “boutique office space.”  (See also entry for Lambda Rising.)

properties.Name: First Congregational Church
properties.Notes: Known as First Church, the Metropolitan Community Church moved here in 1973 from its original Capitol Hill home and remained here until moving to 415 M St NW in 1984.  First Church has also made its home available for AIDS forums, other GLBTQ religious groups, and protest groups.

properties.Name: Furies Collective
properties.Notes: The Furies collective was among Washington, DC's best known communal living groups in the early Seventies.  The collective constituted an important experiment in lesbians of diverse social and economic backgrounds living together and working to make their political and social beliefs in lesbian separatism a day-to-day reality.  Most of the members of the collective wrote for the newspaper which was published from the basement of 219 11th St. SE.  Other members lived in houses at 1861 California St  NW and at 217 12th St SE. From January 1972 until mid-1973, the collective published its groundbreaking newspaper, The Furies, and distributed it nationally.  When the collective disbanded in late spring 1972, "the core of the newspaper staff decided to continue the paper as a project separate from the collective.”

properties.Name: Furies Collective
properties.Notes: he Furies collective was among Washington, DC's best known communal living groups in the early Seventies.  The collective constituted an important experiment in lesbians of diverse social and economic backgrounds living together and working to make their political and social beliefs in lesbian separatism a day-to-day reality.  Most of the members of the collective wrote for the newspaper which was published from the basement of 219 11th St. SE.  Other members lived in houses at 1861 California St  NW and at 219 11th St SE. From January 1972 until mid-1973, the collective published its groundbreaking newspaper, The Furies, and distributed it nationally.  When the collective disbanded in late spring 1972, "the core of the newspaper staff decided to continue the paper as a project separate from the collective.”

properties.Name: Furies Collective
properties.Notes: he Furies collective was among Washington, DC's best known communal living groups in the early Seventies.  The collective constituted an important experiment in lesbians of diverse social and economic backgrounds living together and working to make their political and social beliefs in lesbian separatism a day-to-day reality.  Most of the members of the collective wrote for the newspaper which was published from the basement of 219 11th St. SE.  Other members lived in houses at 219 11th St SE and at 217 12th St SE. From January 1972 until mid-1973, the collective published its groundbreaking newspaper, The Furies, and distributed it nationally.  When the collective disbanded in late spring 1972, "the core of the newspaper staff decided to continue the paper as a project separate from the collective.”

properties.Name: Georgetown Lutheran Church
properties.Notes: Georgetown Lutheran (at Wisconsin and Volta) for many years was the home of the Washington Free Clinic and in November 1973 became the site of the Gay Men’s VD Clinic, a precursor of the Whitman-Walker Clinic.  The Gay Men’s Clinic and a women’s clinic continued at the church until the Whitman-Walker Clinic opened.  (See entries for Whitman-Walker Clinic.)

properties.Name: Grace Episcopal Church
properties.Notes: Grace Episcopal, nicknamed “Amazing Grace,” served as a meeting place and haven for early GLBTQ activist organizations, as well as civil rights and Vietnam antiwar groups.  The Gay Liberation Front formed here in June 1970 and frequently met here until GLF formed its own collective.  During the MayDay protests in 1971, Amazing Grace served as a meeting place and refuge for the antiwar protesters.

properties.Name: Metropolitan Community Church-DC
properties.Notes: The Community Church, founded by Rev. Paul Breton, and meeting originally at All Souls Church, moved to Paul Breton’s home in 1971.  The Community Church became a member of the Universal Fellowship of Metropolitan Community Churches on May 1, 1971.

properties.Name: Metropolitan Community Church-DC
properties.Notes: Having outgrown its Capitol Hill home, the church moved to First Congregational and initially used the church’s small chapel.

properties.Name: SAJA (Special Approaches to Juvenile Assistance)
properties.Notes: SAJA’s offices were the initial meeting site for the DC Coalition of Black Gays after its formation in 1978.  SAJA also arranged the first foster parenting of a gay youth by a member of DC’s gay community (Bruce Pennington).

properties.Name: Saint Margaret’s Episcopal Church
properties.Notes: St. Margaret’s provided the first home for the community’s first counseling group, the Gay Men’s Counseling Collective.  It also welcomed the gay catholic group Dignity when it was forced to leave its home on the Georgetown University campus in 1987.

properties.Name: Saint Mark’s Episcopal Church
properties.Address: 3rd and A Streets SE Washington DC
properties.Notes: St. Mark’s provided meeting space for the fledgling Gay Activists Alliance in the early 1970s.  It was also the first site of early same-sex dances organized by the Mattachine Society of Washington, the Gay Liberation Front, and the Homophile Social League.

properties.Name: Whitman-Walker Clinic
properties.Notes: The Gay Men's VD clinic (1973), the Gay Men's Counseling Collective (1974) and other groups combined and incorporated in 1978 as the Whitman-Walker Clinic, first located at 1606 17th St NW.  Through the years, the Clinic has expanded from general health to become the foremost provider of AIDS services in the area with branches in Virginia, Maryland and the Anacostia area of DC.  Named after Walt Whitman and Dr. Mary Edwards Walker.  (See also entry for Georgetown Lutheran Church.)

properties.Name: Bachelor's Mill
properties.Notes: Moved in 1984 to present location.  Popular multilevel, largely African-American club, with drag shows and bingo on Wednesday evenings, hosted several drag pageants.  Lady Tawanna and Tina Tuna Adams among the drag hostesses.  Drag promoter Marc King worked as club manager at previous location in the 1970s.

properties.Name: Brass Rail
properties.Notes: Started out as "New York style" restaurant at 517 9th St NW in 1966.  On 13th St., started in the basement and didn't move upstairs until the late 60s. First address was 809 13th St. Later became 811 13th St NW. It was one of the main African-American drag bars.  It replaced what was originally a biker, then country/western basement bar.  Owners: Gus Papanicolas, Theo Christakos, Greg Cahill, G W Glenn in 1967.  Brass Rail had moved upstairs by 1973 when Gus Papadopoulos was running the place.  The Railettes were an in-house drag entertainment group.  Just Us:  “The Brass Rail is a downtown bar and restaurant near the downtown shopping areas and the bus terminals.  It has table seating for up to 100 people.  The crowd is male with mixed backgrounds.”

properties.Name: Brass Rail
properties.Notes: The Brass Rail continued fundraisers at its new location through 1994.  The Railettes moved with the bar.

properties.Name: Curiosity Bookstore
properties.Notes: Bookshop for gay books and porn.  Owner:  Lester Randolph

properties.Name: La Zambra
properties.Notes: La Zambra was a major drag and dance spot on the 14th St strip; also called "Lucy's" after Lucy who often bar-walked, to the delight of patrons.  "It was a good place to dance”—Christopher Prince

properties.Name: Marty's
properties.Notes: At the Grand Central location.  Owners Martin Chernoff and Randy Hardwick. Hosted Sunday night lesbian shows organized by Papaya Mann.  (See also entries for Chapter II; Chapter III; and Grand Central.)

properties.Name: Nob Hill Restaurant
properties.Notes: One of the longest continuously operating gay bars in the city, and one of the oldest African-American gay bars in the country.  Reportedly operated as private club from 1953-1957. "Its start as a private club helps explain why it is located in a mostly residential neighborhood in Columbia Heights."--Brett Beemyn.  Owners: James E. Jones, Leonard Kelly, Wayne Hill, Riley Campbell, and Robert Jones. Later bought by Robert Jones, who started here in 1981.  Hosted first AIDS forum in the African-American community.  One of the major sites for African-American drag shows.  Hosted male strip shows on weekends.

properties.Name: 1352 Club
properties.Address: 1352 S Capitol St. SE Washington DC
properties.Notes: A leather/levi disco

properties.Name: Astoria Arms
properties.Notes: Short-lived as a gay bathhouse; also offered entertainment

properties.Name: Bachelor's Mill
properties.Notes: The Mill followed Club Madame at this location (see entry for Club Madame). Owner: BB Gatch.  Arson attack in February 1981.

properties.Name: Ben Bow  Restaurant (The Admiral Ben Bow)
properties.Notes: Next to the Janus Theatre, a straight bar frequented by gays, sawdust on the floor.  First owner: Spirios Kyritis.  An Irish bar run by a woman named Ellen after 1970.  Sawdust and peanut shells on the floor.  Also called the ‘Bimbo”; it was a step down from other places.  Later called Ellen’s Irish Pub.

properties.Name: Buck Stops Here
properties.Notes: Fridays for gays.  The Buck Stops Here was often used for African American GLBT social events by the DC Coalition and black social clubs.

properties.Name: Buddies
properties.Notes: Men's bar in the Union Station area

properties.Name: Carroll Tavern
properties.Notes: Carroll's "catered to a particular gay taste for sailors, soldiers, and marines, and to the armed services' fancy for a free weekend of entertainment."-Havilland Ferris. "In contrast to the genteel atmosphere of Margaret's and Showboat was a bar on 9th street, a rough trade hangout.  Servicemen were very poorly paid at the time and many of them made very aggressive trade."--Ladd Forrester.  "On weekends the place was packed with servicemen from the Army, Marines, and especially the Navy.  A lot of servicemen went there to be picked up; civilians went there to pick them up and take them home for a weekend.  In a sense, you gave them room and board." -- Brett Beemyn.  Owner: Solomon Chesivoir

properties.Name: Chesapeake House
properties.Notes: Owner: John Rock.  One of the last 9th St bars to close, one of the first to feature nude dancers.  Manager John Tonelli murdered in 1978.  A dancer at the Chesapeake was involved in Congressman Robert Bauman's exposure as a gay man.

properties.Name: Club 1140
properties.Notes: Club 1140 was owned by the Clubhouse partners: John Eddy, Morrell Chasten & Andrea Scott.  Had liquor license.  Restaurant called le Maze by day, Club 1140 by night..

properties.Name: Club Washington Bath II
properties.Notes: Also known as Club East II; Club Washington; Club Baths of Washington.  The only bathhouse to survive the 1980s.  Just Us:  “The DC branch of the well-known Club Bath chain is open to members 24 hours a day.  Special features include a sauna room, a sundeck, a TV lounge, a snack bar, and private rooms for relaxing.”  Out (1977) listed Tuesdays as “Levi/Leather Nite.”

properties.Name: Combat Zone
properties.Address: 2122 P St NW rear Washington DC
properties.Notes: Leather-levi bar upstairs at the Fraternity House

properties.Name: Cy's
properties.Notes: Western, levi-leather in upper Georgetown

properties.Name: Dakota
properties.Notes: Dance club, gay and straight, held fundraisers and hosted Ladies of the 80s events

properties.Name: Danny's
properties.Notes: P St Station became Danny's, a piano bar.

properties.Name: Dick's Bar
properties.Address: 639 New York Ave NW Washington DC
properties.Notes: Leather-levi and predecessor of the Eagle at this address

properties.Name: East Side
properties.Notes: Disco

properties.Name: Equus
properties.Notes: Main country-western bar on Capitol Hill.  The bar was attacked by Marines twice in 1982.  (See also entries for Sonny’s; The Life Raft; and Remington’s.)

properties.Name: Exit
properties.Notes: Leather-levi dance club

properties.Name: Fantasies
properties.Notes: Club featured drag performances

properties.Name: Follies
properties.Notes: Owners: Edward Dawson, Martin Crowetz.  Manager Wilson Fitzsimmons. Indicted as 'bawdy house' in November 1992.  One of many SE gay establishments shuttered for construction of the Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Fraternity House
properties.Address: 2122 P St NW rear Washington DC
properties.Notes: Had nude dancers, karaoke, and experimented with 2nd floor restaurant and leather club.  Started Sorority Nights for women on Wednesdays in April 1995.  (See entry for Omega.)

properties.Name: Friends
properties.Notes: Piano bar with pianist Carl Barnwell (who moved to Trumpets after Friends closed). Owners: Jay Lamont , Russ Pepin

properties.Name: Friends - Georgetown
properties.Notes: Piano bar, opening contested by neighborhood groups

properties.Name: Friends - Too
properties.Notes: Piano bar at the Waterfront Mall

properties.Name: General Male
properties.Notes: In the Casino Royale building, the porn shop was originally known as Le Salon

properties.Name: Glorious Health Club
properties.Notes: Owner Bob Siegel.  One of many SE gay establishments shuttered for construction of the Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Hideaway
properties.Notes: Also known as Lou's Hide-a-way. Leather bar.  Dr Franklin Kameny recalls, "The building was at the corner of 9th and Pennsylvania and a street which came in at an angle and no longer exists, but was called Market Place and was an extension, at substantially the same angle, of Indiana Avenue …The entrance to the Hideaway was on 9th Street, and then downstairs; the bar was entirely in the basement of that building.  I believe that the Hideaway was still in operation when the FBI building opened, and I remember hearing stories of FBI agents and other FBI employees having lunch there, before it shifted over, each day, for its evening gay operation."  Just Us:  “A small discotheque in its twelfth year of operation, the Hideaway has intimate tables, shuffleboard, pinball machines, and a jukebox for dancing.  This all contributes to its easy-going atmosphere.  Do cover, no reservations for this predominantly male and highly mixed bar.  One of DC’s standards.  Downstairs from Louie’s and the Barn.”  Out:  “D.C.’s grooviest corner.”

properties.Name: JP's
properties.Notes: Owned by James Papanicolas, opened after Naples closed

properties.Name: JR's
properties.Notes: After Annie's Paramount Steak House moved up 17th St, JR's opened here.  JR's has been a regular sponsor of the annual Halloween High Heel Drag Race since the race started.  Opened by Travis Thorn.

properties.Name: Knickerbocker
properties.Notes: Men's piano bar

properties.Name: Le Salon
properties.Notes: Located in the Casino Royale building, this was a porn shop and one of the last remnants of the 14th St. 'strip'.  It changed its name to General Male in 1987.

properties.Name: Lone Star Café/Beef House
properties.Notes: Originally a steakhouse.  Reputedly the first place to offer nude male dancers.  Owner: Daniel Elias in 1965.

properties.Name: Lost & Found
properties.Notes: The Lost and Found opened in the Fall of 1971 and was almost immediately picketed by the newly formed Committee for Open Gay Bars because of racist and sexist carding policies designed to keep out African-Americans, women, and drag queens.  Original owners were Donn Culver and Bill Bickford.  It became one of the biggest discos in town.  Culver died in a fall from the roof.  Replaced by Quorum in 1991, the name was resurrected in 1993 when Quorum changed its name back to Lost and Found.  Replaced by the Edge.  Just Us:  “Quiet elegance in dining and décor with good disco music re the trademarks of the Lost and Found.  Live band Sunday at 3:00 pm for the tea dance.  No cover except on Halloween and New Year’s.  Reservations are definitely in order for dinner.  Men and women have separate bar areas with different atmosphere, but mingling is constant.  Free popcorn, old prices Tuesday through Thursday nights, pool tables are some special features.  (See also entry for Edge; Quorum; Wet; Zone.)

properties.Name: Louie’s
properties.Notes: Second address for Louis, but same building as above.

properties.Name: Louie’s
properties.Notes: Moved from Pennsylvania Ave due to construction

properties.Name: Lucy's
properties.Notes: Short-lived Georgetown bar

properties.Name: Man's World
properties.Notes: Gay porn, movies, cruising

properties.Name: Mr. P's
properties.Notes: First gay club on the P St. strip. Patio behind the building. George Dotson and Gene Newsome first owners.  John Mako second owner.  Long tradition of drag shows.  Hostesses included Erica Kane, Xavier Bloomingdale, and Marilyn Monroe.  Upstairs bar called the Loft, Monday night leather crowd, Centaurs.

properties.Name: Naples Café
properties.Address: 1209 New York Ave NW Washington DC
properties.Notes: Part of the bus station scene.  A "hustler bar", The Terminal Hotel upstairs rented rooms by the hour.  Owned by Nick Papanicolas. "But the Naples was there forever.  It was there when I arrived in DC in 1956."--Franklin Kameny.    Listed at 1209 in the 50s but at 1227 (under the Terminal Hotel) in 1970s.  James Papanicolas took over after his father Nick died in 1971.  In 1980, Eddie Regina, a waiter was charged by the FBI with trying to blackmail former congressman Robert Bauman.  After Naples closed, Papanicolas opened JP’s on Wisconsin Avenue.  (See entries for Famous Faces, Famous Restaurant, JP’s.)

properties.Name: Naples Café
properties.Address: 1227 New York Ave NW Washington DC
properties.Notes: Part of the bus station scene.  A "hustler bar", The Terminal Hotel upstairs rented rooms by the hour.  Owned by Nick Papanicolas. "But the Naples was there forever.  It was there when I arrived in DC in 1956."--Franklin Kameny.    Listed at 1209 in the 50s but at 1227 (under the Terminal Hotel) in 1970s.  James Papanicolas took over after his father Nick died in 1971.  In 1980, Eddie Regina, a waiter was charged by the FBI with trying to blackmail former congressman Robert Bauman.  After Naples closed, Papanicolas opened JP’s on Wisconsin Avenue.  (See entries for Famous Faces, Famous Restaurant, JP’s.)

properties.Name: Numbers
properties.Notes: A straight bar, with gay events.  Sued for discrimination in 1983

properties.Name: Olympic Baths
properties.Notes: Second to open of the three main 70s era bathhouses, and second to close in the 80s  (followed the Regency in both cases)

properties.Name: Onyx
properties.Notes: Disco club with 3 floors of dancing

properties.Name: Ozone
properties.Notes: Part of Dakota complex, Wednesday night gay dancing.

properties.Name: P St Station
properties.Notes: Succeeded the Fireplace restaurant.  Became Danny's P St Station in 1986, then just Danny's.

properties.Name: Piccolo's
properties.Notes: Country & western bar

properties.Name: Pink Elephant
properties.Notes: Bar at the Hotel Harrington known as a place where hustlers and their clients met.

properties.Name: Powerhouse
properties.Notes: Popular gay gym in the 1980s

properties.Name: Rascals
properties.Notes: Rascals was one of Dupont's major show and dance bars for more than a decade.  Amateur drag shows, hosted by Sparkle MaHaris among others, started many female impersonators' careers.  The top floor (called Shooters) had nude male dancers (also with a separate entrance from the alley).  License suspended in June 92.  December 92, Riggs Bank which owned the building, limited lease renewal to only 1 year.  Rascals decided to close and move across the street.  Owner: Billy Mann.

properties.Name: Regency Baths
properties.Notes: The first gay-oriented bathhouse to open after the Riggs-Lafayette Turkish Baths closed.  David Harris, owner, opened the baths in an old warehouse.  ‘Liz Taylor’ and ‘Judy Garland’ of the Oscars drag group helped in setting up and decorating the baths.  There was a large Roman style mural in the bath area.  Harris had many run-ins with the police who regularly harassed the Regency.  On several occasions the Regency has special women-only nights.  Annual memberships were $12 and the nightly cover was $3.  The Regency was known in later days as a 'hustler' bathhouse, but also as a place where 'street people' could stay the night.  It was indicted as a 'bawdy house' in the 70s and Harris paid a $500 fine. The first of the bathhouses to close during the AIDS epidemic.  Harris also opened Regency bathhouses in Miami, Norfolk, and Boston.  Just Us:  “The Regency is a club open to members only, but membership is open to anyone.  Rates are fifteen dollars a year and are payable in installments.  The club is open 24 hours a day.”

properties.Name: Remington's
properties.Notes: Country-western bar, followed Equus at this location. Owners: Vince Becht, Dick Brandrup & Bill Bickford. Grand Illusions drag show started here in 1996:  Jymmye Jaymes, Blair Michaels, Vita Opulence. Tear gas attack by Marines July 1997.   (See also entries for Equus; The Life Raft; Sonny’s.)

properties.Name: Ricky's Club
properties.Notes: Private club for gay men.  Membership only/

properties.Name: Rogue
properties.Notes: The Rogue was on the third floor of Louis' complex at 9th and Penn.  It followed the Barn and Oscar's Eye theatre.  The rogue had major drag shows.  Ella Fitzgerald was an early performer here.  With development of the 9th St. corridor, Louis and the Rogue moved to 5th and K, where the Rogue still survives but as a straight bar.

properties.Name: Rogue
properties.Notes: Known as Rogue II, the Rogue at 5th & K was in the same building as a restaurant, Stage Door, and Louis.  Over the years, the other two venues disappeared and the Rogue II became a seedy straight bar in a neglected urban zone.  The Brass Rail was a neighbor but didn't last.

properties.Name: Sanctuary
properties.Notes: Briefly replaced Morgan's

properties.Name: Sardi's 5
properties.Notes: It was next to Jerry's Marquis de Sade, same owner.  Reportedly offered some drag shows.

properties.Name: Secrets
properties.Notes: Behind Ziegfeld’s, featured nude dancers.  One of the businesses closed down by the city to build the Washington Nationals ballpark.  (See also entry for Ziegfeld’s.)

properties.Name: Shooters
properties.Notes: Entrance behind Rascals.  Nude male dancers on top floor of Rascals.

properties.Name: Stage Door
properties.Notes: A restaurant opened when Louis' and the Rogue moved to 5th & K

properties.Name: Strap
properties.Notes: Men's leather bar

properties.Name: Whispers and Secrets
properties.Notes: Bar and drag club owned by Dana Terrell, leading female impersonator and drag promoter.

properties.Name: Paul Lawrence Dunbar Home
properties.Notes: Reputedly bisexual, Dunbar moved here with his mother  and wife while working at the Library of Congress.

properties.Name: Eagle
properties.Notes: Levi-leather, became Washington Eagle until move to New York Ave.

properties.Name: Eagle (DC)
properties.Address: 639 New York Ave NW Washington DC
properties.Notes: Latest location for DC's classic levi-leather club.  Home to many community fundraisers.

properties.Name: Eagle in Exile
properties.Notes: The leather/levi dance place.  Around the corner from the Rogue/Brass Rail at 5th and K.

properties.Name: Eagle in Exile
properties.Notes: Levi-leather club, doorman shot in robbery in 1982.  Owner Lou Ritz died February 1985

properties.Name: Leather Rack
properties.Notes: Leather-levi store, above Eagle

properties.Name: Leather Rack
properties.Notes: Leather-levi store, upstairs.

properties.Name: Backdoor Pub
properties.Notes: A second floor bar with large windows overlooking the intersection of 8th St and E St SE.  Patrons, mostly African American, entered from a door on the E St. side.  The club had a pool table and card tables, where “there always seemed to be a bid whist game going on.”

properties.Name: Backdoor Pub
properties.Notes: Moved in 1988, co-owner Charles A Jones.  Part of the Bachelor's Mill complex.

properties.Name: Clubhouse
properties.Notes: A disco without a regular liquor license. Famous for its 'acid punch'.  A membership club and premier dance club for the African-American gay and lesbian community.  It grew out of the Zodiac Den and Third World.  Fundraiser/community support helped keep it going in late 80s, supported by Best of Washington & Associates. Known for its Children's Hour events on Sundays.  Site of the AIDS forum for the African-American community in 1983. Owners: Aundrea Scott, John Eddy, Chasten Morrell.  Managed by Ray Melrose and Rainey Cheeks.  Featured Master DJ Tito Robinson.

properties.Name: Pier Nine
properties.Notes: Commonly known as the Pier.  The second major dance club, after the Plus One (8th St SE), and opened by the same owners as the Plus One.  Original owners: Donn Culver & Bill Bickford (who later opened the Lost & Found). The Pier had a second floor dance area, a popular restaurant, and in the 70s an area on the ground floor for those under the legal drinking age.   The Pier 9 was the first gay dance club in the South Capitol St. area.  In 1975, the Washington Square opened on the other side of South Capital St. at 1345 Half St SE.  Just Us (1974):  “Glitter, fashion, and jammy music are the general rule at the Pier, but anything goes.  Two dance floors (upstairs and down) and a number of bars, and a restaurant serving dinner, pizzas, and ‘heavenly burgers’ are some specialties.  One dollar cover on Friday and Saturday.”  “Given its relatively isolated location, it gave us a sense of security that more in-town locations couldn’t”—Peter Jefts.

properties.Name: 930 Club
properties.Notes: Straight music venue with gay evenings

properties.Name: Annie's Paramount Steak House
properties.Notes: Originally known as Paramount Steakhouse until the 1960s.  A favorite restaurant hangout on 17th St strip

properties.Name: Annie's Paramount Steak House
properties.Notes: Popular steakhouse and bar.

properties.Name: Badlands
properties.Notes: Popular Dupont dance bar, managed by Sophie Tucker (Don Gilliken) for many years.   Home for many years of the Miss Capitol Pride pageant.  Accused of carding in the early 1980s.  Video bar, Annex, upstairs.  (See also entries for Apex; Phase One of Dupont.)

properties.Name: Chapter III
properties.Notes: Successor to Marty's at this location. Owned by Martin Chernoff (part owner of Marty's).  Tried to attract a straight crowd.  (See also entries for Chapter II; Grand Central; Marty’s.)

properties.Name: Cities
properties.Notes: A mixed straight and gay club, held fundraisers and hosted Ladies of the 80s events.  (See entry for Club 2424.)

properties.Name: Dot's Spot
properties.Notes: Upstairs, over Mr. Henry's.  Owner: Dot Palmerton

properties.Name: Fifth Column
properties.Notes: Straight dance club had frequent fundraisers and gay nights.  Hosted regular gay night, called Atlas, on Sundays.

properties.Name: Glory Hole
properties.Notes: Owner Bob Siegel

properties.Name: Mr. Henry's - Georgetown
properties.Notes: Owned by Larry Samuel, who bought it from Henry Yaffe in 1973

properties.Name: Paramount Steak House
properties.Notes: Annie's was originally known as Paramount Steakhouse until the 1960s.  A favorite restaurant hangout on 17th St strip.  (See also entries for Annie’s Paramount Steak House.)

properties.Name: TJ's Steakhouse
properties.Notes: Steakhouse restaurant and bar

properties.Name: Tracks
properties.Notes: Popular dance club in SE.  Owners: Kim Postzman, Randy Hardwick.  Lesbo-agogo on Tuesdays started in July 1991.

properties.Name: Westwood Restaurant
properties.Notes: Popular after-hours diner in Silver Spring.

properties.Name: Ziegfeld's
properties.Notes: Club that followed the Other Side at this location.  Backroom (Secrets) had nude male dancers.  Ziegfeld's hosted drag shows Thursday through Sunday.  Ella Fitzgerald hostess and show director.  Thursday nights were hosted by Sabrina White, Vita Opulence and others.  Owners: Chris Jansen, Allen Carroll.  Closed by eminent domain to use site for Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Coffeehouse
properties.Notes: Also known as the ENIK Alley Coffehouse.  An arts & literature center in a two story carriage house building behind a house at 816 I St NE. DCCBG & Ray Melrose founded the Coffeehouse.  It hosted the Sapphire Sapphos, and was taken over by Sapphire Sapphos in November 1984.  With an open loft overlooking the main floor, a fireplace and a warm atmosphere, the place was unique among gay and lesbian spaces in DC.  The coffeehouse was a crucible for artists, writers, musicians, and performance artists.  When Melrose moved to the DC Space, many of the performers at the Coffeehouse joined him there.

properties.Name: Gay Community Center
properties.Notes: The second community center was organized with support from the Washington Area Gay Community Council, which started discussions about a community center in 1978.  It provided meeting space for community groups but had trouble collecting fees.  Was also home to OUT University classes.

properties.Name: Gay Community Center
properties.Notes: James Crutchfield, President, 1982 – 1988.

properties.Name: Gay Community Center
properties.Notes: Offered AIDS support groups in late 1980s.  Ran into financial difficulties in 1989, evicted in November 1990.  Last president Bob Roehr.  (See entry for DC Center.)

properties.Name: Essie
properties.Notes: Run by the Sapphire Sapphos at the Coffeehouse.  (See also entry for the Coffeehouse.)

properties.Name: Studio
properties.Notes: A women's bar near SE DC

properties.Name: Harlow
properties.Notes: A women's bar, owned by Buddies

properties.Name: Hill Haven
properties.Notes: Capitol Hill women's bar, opened a restaurant in August 1990.  Two controversies erupted in 1991.  The club was boycotted by black lesbians protesting perceived racism.  It was then exposed as not being "lesbian-owned" or even woman-owned in 1991, contrary to its advertising.  It came under new management January 1992.  In August 1991 Hill Haven started men's night on Wednesdays.

properties.Name: Hung Jury
properties.Notes: One of the longest running women's bars in the city; dancing.

properties.Name: Li'l Sister
properties.Notes: A women's bar, Fridays and Saturdays

properties.Name: Other Side
properties.Notes: Women's dance and drag bar.  Replaced Blue Plains Dance Palace.  Ella Fitzgerald appeared in and later hosted drag shows here.

properties.Name: Zombies Restaurant
properties.Notes: A mixed crowd but primarily women.  Zombies courted the gay women's' business and then the straight crowd.  In the early 70s the owners tried to discourage lesbian customers but lost business and returned to encouraging lesbian customers.  Owners: James and Pearl Lake.

properties.Name: Lammas
properties.Notes: Founded by as a craft store by Judy Winsett and Leslie Reeves, and later owned by Mary Farmer, Lammas became a bookstore, community center for lesbians, and a performance space.  .  "What an incredible institution Lammas is.  It's been enormously valuable to this community, particularly the women's and the Lesbian and Gay community."--Ivy Young.  Just Us:  “Lammas specializes in custom-made jewelry and women’s arts and crafts, and carries records as well.  The management promotes and encourages women’s arts, activities, and events, such as softball teams and feature artists.  The shop is owned and operated by Lesbians.”  Lammas also had a mail-order house called First Things First.

properties.Name: Lammas
properties.Notes: Cultural center and bookstore for DC lesbian and feminist community.  Mary Farmer sold Lammas to Jane Troxell, Rosa Fennell, Marge Darling & Susan Fletcher in March 1993

properties.Name: Washington Area Women's Center
properties.Notes: Last home of the Women's Center

properties.Name: Cagney's
properties.Notes: Dupont Circle dance bar

properties.Name: Cheers
properties.Notes: After hours gay club run by Raymond Carter.  Raided by MPD March 14, 1987.

properties.Name: Collector
properties.Notes: Gay-oriented restaurant.

properties.Name: Faith Temple
properties.Address: 1313 New York Avenue NW Washington DC
properties.Notes: Founded in 1982 by Dr. James S Tinney, a Howard University political scientist and Pentecostal theologian who was forced to leave his church because of his sexual orientation.  The congregation originally met at Calvary Methodist in Columbia Heights

properties.Name: Montana
properties.Notes: Next to the Dakota

properties.Name: Terminal Hotel
properties.Notes: Hotel rooms above the Naples Café rented by the hour for 'short term assignations'.   Used by gay sex workers.  Owner:  Nick Papanicolas

properties.Name: Wayward Books
properties.Notes: Noted lesbian author Doris Grumbach (Entering the End Zone, The Ladies, etc.) and her partner Sylvia Pike owned a second-hand book store called Wayward Books just two stores away from Lammas and next door to the Post Office.  The shop was furnished with comfortable armchairs for readers to use while browsing the books.

properties.Name: The Community Building
properties.Notes: Connected to counterculture and anti-war activity.  Among many groups to meet there (Black Panthers Defense Committee; Washington Area Free University, etc.), it housed off our backs, the Gay Switchboard, the Blade, and the original Lambda Rising.  “We used to joke that the building was only held together by all the wiretaps the FBI had placed there”—Deacon Maccubbin.  The last gay-specific organizations moved out in the 1980s; as of 2012, the building is advertised as “boutique office space.”  (See also entry for Lambda Rising.)

properties.Name: First Congregational Church
properties.Notes: Known as First Church, the Metropolitan Community Church moved here in 1973 from its original Capitol Hill home and remained here until moving to 415 M St NW in 1984.  First Church has also made its home available for AIDS forums, other GLBTQ religious groups, and protest groups.

properties.Name: Metropolitan Community Church-DC
properties.Notes: Having outgrown its Capitol Hill home, the church moved to First Congregational and initially used the church’s small chapel.

properties.Name: Metropolitan Community Church-DC
properties.Notes: In 1984, MCC-DC bought the property at 415 M St NW, a site formerly home to Hebrew congregations and youth groups, and moved into its first owned home

properties.Name: SAJA (Special Approaches to Juvenile Assistance)
properties.Notes: SAJA’s offices were the initial meeting site for the DC Coalition of Black Gays after its formation in 1978.  SAJA also arranged the first foster parenting of a gay youth by a member of DC’s gay community (Bruce Pennington).

properties.Name: Wrenchwoman
properties.Notes: Lesbian owned and operated car repair company, early example of lesbian self-reliance and entrepreneurship

properties.Name: Brass Rail
properties.Notes: The Brass Rail continued fundraisers at its new location through 1994.  The Railettes moved with the bar.

properties.Name: Circle
properties.Notes: When Rascals closed in December 1992,after suspension of its liquor license and Riggs' refusal to renew the lease beyond 1 year, the owners applied to transfer the liquor license across the street to 1629 Connecticut.  The new location, the Circle, took a year to get its liquor license transferred from Rascal's location.  The Circle became a very popular bar for African-American and white gay men.  The Sunday evening happy hour had lines down the street waiting to get in.

properties.Name: Full House
properties.Notes: African-American club on Capitol Hill.

properties.Name: Nob Hill Restaurant
properties.Notes: One of the longest continuously operating gay bars in the city, and one of the oldest African-American gay bars in the country.  Reportedly operated as private club from 1953-1957. "Its start as a private club helps explain why it is located in a mostly residential neighborhood in Columbia Heights."--Brett Beemyn.  Owners: James E. Jones, Leonard Kelly, Wayne Hill, Riley Campbell, and Robert Jones. Later bought by Robert Jones, who started here in 1981.  Hosted first AIDS forum in the African-American community.  One of the major sites for African-American drag shows.  Hosted male strip shows on weekends.

properties.Name: Sugar Kane Palace
properties.Notes: An African-American gay club on the site of the former Third World.  (See also entries for Third World; Zodiac Den.)

properties.Name: Arizona
properties.Notes: Bar & grill, dancing

properties.Name: Boy
properties.Notes: Short-lived gay dance night on Wednesdays

properties.Name: Cadmus Books
properties.Notes: Bookshop with some gay porn etc

properties.Name: Chesapeake House
properties.Notes: Owner: John Rock.  One of the last 9th St bars to close, one of the first to feature nude dancers.  Manager John Tonelli murdered in 1978.  A dancer at the Chesapeake was involved in Congressman Robert Bauman's exposure as a gay man.

properties.Name: Club Washington Bath II
properties.Notes: Also known as Club East II; Club Washington; Club Baths of Washington.  The only bathhouse to survive the 1980s.  Just Us:  “The DC branch of the well-known Club Bath chain is open to members 24 hours a day.  Special features include a sauna room, a sundeck, a TV lounge, a snack bar, and private rooms for relaxing.”  Out (1977) listed Tuesdays as “Levi/Leather Nite.”

properties.Name: Cobalt
properties.Notes: Above Fonda del Sol restaurant, Featured dancing, drag, women's nights.  Club burned down in December 1998.  Drag show moved to Omega.  Re-opened October 2001.  Features drag bingo and Feygele Feud, starring Lena Lett (2001-2002), which was eventually the subject of lawsuits over who had created the idea.  Since 2002, features upstairs bar called 30 Degrees.

properties.Name: Crew Club
properties.Notes: Health club, bathhouse.  Owner: DC Allen

properties.Name: Crypt
properties.Notes: Leather/fetish bar next to the Edge

properties.Name: Dakota
properties.Notes: Dance club, gay and straight, held fundraisers and hosted Ladies of the 80s events

properties.Name: Edge
properties.Notes: Followed the Lost & Found at this location.  Manager: Jeff Neal.  Licenses suspended December 1998 for fights.  (See also entries for Lost & Found; Quorum; Wet; Zone.)

properties.Name: Fireplace
properties.Notes: The Fireplace was a restaurant at this location in the 50s; after being known as P St. Station, it returned to being the Fireplace.  Judy, popular bartender/waitress of the Georgetown Grill, works here.  Much of the crowd from the Circle moved here after the Circle closed in 2000.

properties.Name: Follies
properties.Notes: Owners: Edward Dawson, Martin Crowetz.  Manager Wilson Fitzsimmons. Indicted as 'bawdy house' in November 1992.  One of many SE gay establishments shuttered for construction of the Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Fraternity House
properties.Address: 2122 P St NW rear Washington DC
properties.Notes: Had nude dancers, karaoke, and experimented with 2nd floor restaurant and leather club.  Started Sorority Nights for women on Wednesdays in April 1995.  (See entry for Omega.)

properties.Name: Friends
properties.Notes: Piano bar with pianist Carl Barnwell (who moved to Trumpets after Friends closed). Owners: Jay Lamont , Russ Pepin

properties.Name: Glorious Health Club
properties.Notes: Owner Bob Siegel.  One of many SE gay establishments shuttered for construction of the Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Green Lantern
properties.Notes: At the same location as the 1920s Krazy Kat.  Disco bar behind 1313 L St NW.  Fined and closed twice (September 1996 and March 1997) by the ABC for violation of liquor laws/fondling of nude dancers.  Re-opened in same location October 2001.  ToolShed, an upstairs bar, mostly leather.  Owner from 2001: Greg Zehnacker

properties.Name: Jenkins Hill/Underground
properties.Notes: Jenkins Hill Underground advertised as a "lesbian and gay nightclub" that offered a bar, pool and darts

properties.Name: Jenny's Lounge
properties.Notes: Weekend dance club on SW waterfront that also hosted drag pageants and drag shows.

properties.Name: Lizard Lounge
properties.Notes: Gay male dance night at the Saint, Sundays.  Moved from 1520 14th St to 1223 Club on CT Ave.  Founder Mark Lee shut the promotion down when D.C. banned indoor smoking.

properties.Name: Lizard Lounge
properties.Notes: Gay male dance night at the Saint, Sundays.  Moved from 1520 14th St to 1223 Club on CT Ave.  Founder Mark Lee shut the promotion down when D.C. banned indoor smoking.

properties.Name: Lost & Found
properties.Notes: The Lost and Found opened in the Fall of 1971 and was almost immediately picketed by the newly formed Committee for Open Gay Bars because of racist and sexist carding policies designed to keep out African-Americans, women, and drag queens.  Original owners were Donn Culver and Bill Bickford.  It became one of the biggest discos in town.  Culver died in a fall from the roof.  Replaced by Quorum in 1991, the name was resurrected in 1993 when Quorum changed its name back to Lost and Found.  Replaced by the Edge.  Just Us:  “Quiet elegance in dining and décor with good disco music re the trademarks of the Lost and Found.  Live band Sunday at 3:00 pm for the tea dance.  No cover except on Halloween and New Year’s.  Reservations are definitely in order for dinner.  Men and women have separate bar areas with different atmosphere, but mingling is constant.  Free popcorn, old prices Tuesday through Thursday nights, pool tables are some special features.  (See also entry for Edge; Quorum; Wet; Zone.)

properties.Name: Mr. P's
properties.Notes: First gay club on the P St. strip. Patio behind the building. George Dotson and Gene Newsome first owners.  John Mako second owner.  Long tradition of drag shows.  Hostesses included Erica Kane, Xavier Bloomingdale, and Marilyn Monroe.  Upstairs bar called the Loft, Monday night leather crowd, Centaurs.

properties.Name: Omega
properties.Address: 2122 P St NW rear Washington DC
properties.Notes: The Fraternity House changed its name and décor to Omega.  The dance floor was removed.  After Cobalt burned (1998), Omega became the site of a Monday night drag show hosted by J C Van Raine. Popular Thursday night karaoke show.  Owner: Glenn Thompson.  Building sold at the end of 2012, shutting down the club.

properties.Name: Opera
properties.Notes: Popular dance club replaced Dakota

properties.Name: Ozone
properties.Notes: Part of Dakota complex, Wednesday night gay dancing.

properties.Name: Ozone
properties.Notes: Saturday gay dancing.  Nude dancers on Fridays.  Women's night started in October 1997.

properties.Name: P St Station
properties.Notes: Succeeded the Fireplace restaurant.  Became Danny's P St Station in 1986, then just Danny's.

properties.Name: Parachute
properties.Notes: Warehouse disco.  Later replaced in this location by the 9:30 Club.  (See also entry for 9:30 Club.)

properties.Name: Pump Room
properties.Notes: Tuesday evening gay men’s night at the Chicago club

properties.Name: Quorum
properties.Notes: Disco bar in former Lost & Found building but resurrected the Lost & Found name in late 1992, and changed back to the Lost & Found name in the summer of 1993.  (See also entries for Edge; Lost & Found; Wet; Zone.)

properties.Name: Rascals
properties.Notes: Rascals was one of Dupont's major show and dance bars for more than a decade.  Amateur drag shows, hosted by Sparkle MaHaris among others, started many female impersonators' careers.  The top floor (called Shooters) had nude male dancers (also with a separate entrance from the alley).  License suspended in June 92.  December 92, Riggs Bank which owned the building, limited lease renewal to only 1 year.  Rascals decided to close and move across the street.  Owner: Billy Mann.

properties.Name: Rogue
properties.Notes: Known as Rogue II, the Rogue at 5th & K was in the same building as a restaurant, Stage Door, and Louis.  Over the years, the other two venues disappeared and the Rogue II became a seedy straight bar in a neglected urban zone.  The Brass Rail was a neighbor but didn't last.

properties.Name: Secrets
properties.Notes: Behind Ziegfeld’s, featured nude dancers.  One of the businesses closed down by the city to build the Washington Nationals ballpark.  (See also entry for Ziegfeld’s.)

properties.Name: Shooters
properties.Notes: Entrance behind Rascals.  Nude male dancers on top floor of Rascals.

properties.Name: UnderGround
properties.Notes: Underground was meant to be a monthly event with a new location each month.  The circulating party did not circulate for long.

properties.Name: Wave, The
properties.Address: 1731 New Hampshire Ave NW Washington DC
properties.Notes: A club at the Carlyle Suites hotel.

properties.Name: Wet
properties.Notes: Followed Lost & Found and Quorum at this location.  (See also entries for Edge; Lost & Found; Quorum; Zone.)

properties.Name: Windows
properties.Notes: Above Dupont Italian Kitchen restaurant; nicknamed "widows,” after its predominantly older crowd.  (See also entry for DIK Bar.)

properties.Name: Zone
properties.Notes: When Quorum took over the Lost & Found, the Zone opened "a video pool hall for the 90s."  With nude male dancers.  Wet replaced it.  (See also entries for Edge; Lost & Found; Quorum; Wet.)

properties.Name: Paul Lawrence Dunbar Home
properties.Notes: Reputedly bisexual, Dunbar moved here with his mother  and wife while working at the Library of Congress.

properties.Name: Clubhouse
properties.Notes: A disco without a regular liquor license. Famous for its 'acid punch'.  A membership club and premier dance club for the African-American gay and lesbian community.  It grew out of the Zodiac Den and Third World.  Fundraiser/community support helped keep it going in late 80s, supported by Best of Washington & Associates. Known for its Children's Hour events on Sundays.  Site of the AIDS forum for the African-American community in 1983. Owners: Aundrea Scott, John Eddy, Chasten Morrell.  Managed by Ray Melrose and Rainey Cheeks.  Featured Master DJ Tito Robinson.

properties.Name: Encore Social Club
properties.Notes: Off New York Avenue and Fenwick NE.  The Encore followed the closing of the Clubhouse as a center, with raps and discussions, fundraisers for ICAN, Raymond Carter manager

properties.Name: Deco Cabana
properties.Notes: Latino club that followed Escandalo at this location, drag shows, popular late 90s.

properties.Name: El Faro
properties.Notes: 2nd floor, First Latino gay club in DC.  Owner: Oscar Guardado.  The club drew a lot of hostility leading to violence that undermined its drawing power.  Ana Maria Morales killed in front of El Faro in January 1993.  Five customers assaulted in front of El Faro in March 1993.  Accused killer of Morales acquitted.

properties.Name: Escandalo
properties.Notes: Latino gay club became very popular, 'community center', for young Latinos and Latinas.  Popular drag shows.  Owner: Roberto Hermasillo.  Paired with Lonestar West restaurant.

properties.Name: 1409 Playbill Café
properties.Notes: Popular restaurant, featuring drag bingo and performance art

properties.Name: 17th St Bar & Grill
properties.Address: 1615 Rhode Island Ave NW Washington DC
properties.Notes: Popular Sunday brunch, in Governor's House Hotel

properties.Name: 801 Club
properties.Notes: Replaced the Blue Penguin

properties.Name: 930 Club
properties.Notes: Straight music venue with gay evenings

properties.Name: 9:30 Club
properties.Notes: Second location of 9:30 Club.  Beginning in September 1997 (until ?) hosted Millennium, a Saturday night dance party.  Frequent host of Blowoff event for the bear community.

properties.Name: Badlands
properties.Notes: Popular Dupont dance bar, managed by Sophie Tucker (Don Gilliken) for many years.   Home for many years of the Miss Capitol Pride pageant.  Accused of carding in the early 1980s.  Video bar, Annex, upstairs.  (See also entries for Apex; Phase One of Dupont.)

properties.Name: Banana Café
properties.Notes: Cuban restaurant is the latest gay enterprise at this location.  (See entry for Johnnie’s.)

properties.Name: Bent (at the Andalusian Dog)
properties.Notes: "For the Hipper Homo", dance club

properties.Name: Black Cat
properties.Notes: Drew gay crowd on Saturday nights, lesbian shows late 90s.  Home of the popular women's program Mothertongue.

properties.Name: Blue Penguin
properties.Notes: Restaurant, bar and dance floor.  Hosted drag and karaoke shows.

properties.Name: Chaos
properties.Notes: Replaced the short-lived Q Club.  Original owners:  Wes Sullivan, Carlos Aguilar. Chaos became a very diverse club with Latino, women's, and drag nights. Drag bingo (Tues), women’s night (Wed.) drag show (Sat), Latino drag (Fri.).  Hosted DC's only regularly scheduled drag kings show.  Among other show hosts have been Lena Lett, Leona Hemsley, Xavier Bloomingdale, Jordan Taylor, Gigi Couture, and Regina Joezet.

properties.Name: Cities
properties.Notes: A mixed straight and gay club, held fundraisers and hosted Ladies of the 80s events.  (See entry for Club 2424.)

properties.Name: Club 2424
properties.Notes: Cities became Club 2424 in February 1990

properties.Name: Club Vanity
properties.Notes: Mixed club for men and women, replaced Li'l Sister

properties.Name: Coyote Bar & Grill
properties.Notes: Dupont area hangout.

properties.Name: Diversite
properties.Notes: 14th St. dance club, hosted a few drag pageants in the late 90s

properties.Name: Franklyn's
properties.Notes: 18th St. coffeeshop with leather influence.  Regularly hosts fundraisers for the drag and leather communities

properties.Name: Larry's Lounge
properties.Notes: Advertised as a "neighborhood bar and coffeehouse.”  Owner Lawrence Tan and his partner expanded next door to their own restaurant, Straits of Malaya, which had been operating since 1989 (and closed in 2010).

properties.Name: Our Place
properties.Notes: Community restaurant, fundraisers

properties.Name: Results, the Gym
properties.Notes: `Gay health club of the 90s, very popular.  Expanded to other locations in 2001.

properties.Name: Sheridan's Dance Hall & Saloon
properties.Notes: Country & western restaurant and dance club.  Hosted drag bingo Wednesday nights and drag pageants.  Owner: Sandy Thompson

properties.Name: Soho Tea and Coffee
properties.Notes: Coffeehouse on the SE corner of P and 22nd St.  Soho was popular  in the 1990s with SMYAL-aged gay and lesbian youth.  Art shows, occasional musical performances.  Lesbian-owned.

properties.Name: Stage Door
properties.Notes: Restaurant

properties.Name: Tracks
properties.Notes: Popular dance club in SE.  Owners: Kim Postzman, Randy Hardwick.  Lesbo-agogo on Tuesdays started in July 1991.

properties.Name: Trumpets
properties.Notes: Popular restaurant with jazz brunch on Sundays.

properties.Name: Velvet Nation
properties.Address: S Capitol & K St SE Washington DC
properties.Notes: Saturday night gay night at the Nation nightclub.  Ed Bailey and John Guggenmos, producers.   Popular gay dance club closed due to development around a new baseball stadium site.

properties.Name: Wild Oates
properties.Notes: Country-western dance bar opened by Bill Oates Jr and Travis Thorn.

properties.Name: Zei Alley
properties.Notes: Club that hosted a variety of gay dance nights, including Atlas (and later Tantrum) on Friday nights.

properties.Name: Ziegfeld's
properties.Notes: Club that followed the Other Side at this location.  Backroom (Secrets) had nude male dancers.  Ziegfeld's hosted drag shows Thursday through Sunday.  Ella Fitzgerald hostess and show director.  Thursday nights were hosted by Sabrina White, Vita Opulence and others.  Owners: Chris Jansen, Allen Carroll.  Closed by eminent domain to use site for Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Coffeehouse
properties.Notes: Also known as the ENIK Alley Coffehouse.  An arts & literature center in a two story carriage house building behind a house at 816 I St NE. DCCBG & Ray Melrose founded the Coffeehouse.  It hosted the Sapphire Sapphos, and was taken over by Sapphire Sapphos in November 1984.  With an open loft overlooking the main floor, a fireplace and a warm atmosphere, the place was unique among gay and lesbian spaces in DC.  The coffeehouse was a crucible for artists, writers, musicians, and performance artists.  When Melrose moved to the DC Space, many of the performers at the Coffeehouse joined him there.

properties.Name: Gay Community Center
properties.Notes: Offered AIDS support groups in late 1980s.  Ran into financial difficulties in 1989, evicted in November 1990.  Last president Bob Roehr.  (See entry for DC Center.)

properties.Name: Essie
properties.Notes: Run by the Sapphire Sapphos at the Coffeehouse.  (See also entry for the Coffeehouse.)

properties.Name: Elan
properties.Notes: On the 2nd floor. Women's bar, had Wednesday evening drag shows hosted by Michelle Michaels and Courtney Lovelace.

properties.Name: Ellington's on 8th
properties.Notes: Women's club on Sundays

properties.Name: Hill Haven
properties.Notes: Capitol Hill women's bar, opened a restaurant in August 1990.  Two controversies erupted in 1991.  The club was boycotted by black lesbians protesting perceived racism.  It was then exposed as not being "lesbian-owned" or even woman-owned in 1991, contrary to its advertising.  It came under new management January 1992.  In August 1991 Hill Haven started men's night on Wednesdays.

properties.Name: Hung Jury
properties.Notes: One of the longest running women's bars in the city; dancing.

properties.Name: Jojo's
properties.Notes: Special women's night on Saturdays, for 'progressive women', at Hill Haven

properties.Name: Li'l Sister
properties.Notes: A women's bar, Fridays and Saturdays

properties.Name: Out of the Blue II
properties.Notes: Second incarnation of original women's club that met above LoneStar East. Lasted about 6 months

properties.Name: Sophisticated Ladies
properties.Notes: A Saturday night women's club at G & G Italian Villa, which later became an organizer and promoter of women’s events.  Vicki Harris organized many of Sophisticated Ladies events, including women’s nights at Wet.

properties.Name: Spy Club
properties.Notes: Spy Club had Sunday night women's parties

properties.Name: Venus
properties.Notes: Women's bar, open Friday and Saturday nights.

properties.Name: Womon
properties.Address: 19th St at Dupont Circle Washington DC
properties.Notes: Sunday night women's night at Chicago dance club.

properties.Name: Lammas
properties.Notes: Cultural center and bookstore for DC lesbian and feminist community.  Mary Farmer sold Lammas to Jane Troxell, Rosa Fennell, Marge Darling & Susan Fletcher in March 1993

properties.Name: Washington Area Women's Center
properties.Notes: Last home of the Women's Center

properties.Name: Lambda Literary Foundation
properties.Notes: LGBT literary foundation incorporated by Jim Marks.  Originally located in the carriage house behind Lambda Rising’s Connecticut Ave. location.  Published Lambda Book Report and was the second publisher for the gay men’s literary journal The James White Review.  Also ran the Lambda Literary Awards and several Behind Our Masks LGBT writers’ conferences.

properties.Name: Q Club
properties.Notes: Short-lived club that replaced Trumpets.  Carl Barnwell, pianist from Friends, played here.

properties.Name: Wayward Books
properties.Notes: Noted lesbian author Doris Grumbach (Entering the End Zone, The Ladies, etc.) and her partner Sylvia Pike owned a second-hand book store called Wayward Books just two stores away from Lammas and next door to the Post Office.  The shop was furnished with comfortable armchairs for readers to use while browsing the books.

properties.Name: Metropolitan Community Church-DC
properties.Notes: In 1984, MCC-DC bought the property at 415 M St NW, a site formerly home to Hebrew congregations and youth groups, and moved into its first owned home

properties.Name: Metropolitan Community Church-DC
properties.Notes: MCC-DC built its new sanctuary at the corner of 5th and Ridge Streets NW and celebrated its first event there at Christmas 1992.

properties.Name: Townhouse Tavern
properties.Notes: Local "dive-bar" in Dupont Circle;  site of a federal cocaine sting in 2011.

properties.Name: Circle
properties.Notes: When Rascals closed in December 1992,after suspension of its liquor license and Riggs' refusal to renew the lease beyond 1 year, the owners applied to transfer the liquor license across the street to 1629 Connecticut.  The new location, the Circle, took a year to get its liquor license transferred from Rascal's location.  The Circle became a very popular bar for African-American and white gay men.  The Sunday evening happy hour had lines down the street waiting to get in.

properties.Name: Nob Hill Restaurant
properties.Notes: One of the longest continuously operating gay bars in the city, and one of the oldest African-American gay bars in the country.  Reportedly operated as private club from 1953-1957. "Its start as a private club helps explain why it is located in a mostly residential neighborhood in Columbia Heights."--Brett Beemyn.  Owners: James E. Jones, Leonard Kelly, Wayne Hill, Riley Campbell, and Robert Jones. Later bought by Robert Jones, who started here in 1981.  Hosted first AIDS forum in the African-American community.  One of the major sites for African-American drag shows.  Hosted male strip shows on weekends.

properties.Name: Andalu
properties.Notes: Deep End: Wednesday night for gay crowd started in 2000; moved to 1355 H St. NE in early 2003.

properties.Name: Ardiente
properties.Notes: Latin disco and drag shows on Fridays and Saturdays, organized by the Carrero sisters.  Moved to Sheridan's in mid-2001

properties.Name: Club Ten
properties.Notes: A short-lived leather bar that opened in the old Pier Nine building, Club Ten never attracted enough patrons to keep it going.

properties.Name: Club Washington Bath II
properties.Notes: Also known as Club East II; Club Washington; Club Baths of Washington.  The only bathhouse to survive the 1980s.  Just Us:  “The DC branch of the well-known Club Bath chain is open to members 24 hours a day.  Special features include a sauna room, a sundeck, a TV lounge, a snack bar, and private rooms for relaxing.”  Out (1977) listed Tuesdays as “Levi/Leather Nite.”

properties.Name: DIK Bar
properties.Notes: Bar for men above the Dupont Italian Kitchen; formerly (and still frequently) known as Windows.  (See also entry for Windows.)

properties.Name: Edge
properties.Notes: Followed the Lost & Found at this location.  Manager: Jeff Neal.  Licenses suspended December 1998 for fights.  (See also entries for Lost & Found; Quorum; Wet; Zone.)

properties.Name: Follies
properties.Notes: Owners: Edward Dawson, Martin Crowetz.  Manager Wilson Fitzsimmons. Indicted as 'bawdy house' in November 1992.  One of many SE gay establishments shuttered for construction of the Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Glorious Health Club
properties.Notes: Owner Bob Siegel.  One of many SE gay establishments shuttered for construction of the Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Glorious Health Club Spa & Art Gallery
properties.Address: 2120 West Virginia Avenue NE Washington DC
properties.Notes: Owner Bob Siegel.  Men’s spa and steam room.  Relocated following closure of 24 O St SE location.  Added “Art Gallery’ to title in June 2007 after temporary closure by the city.  Alternately known as 2120 Club.

properties.Name: Heat
properties.Notes: Men’s bar, replaced La Cage aux Follies.  Nude male dancers. Owner Bob Siegel.  Taken by eminent domain to build baseball stadium.

properties.Name: Kingdom
properties.Notes: Sunday evening for gay men at the re-opened Bohemian Caverns.  The site was one of the earliest African-American and white gay meeting places, as the Crystal Caverns, in the 1930s.

properties.Name: Lizard Lounge
properties.Notes: Gay male dance night at the Saint, Sundays.  Moved from 1520 14th St to 1223 Club on CT Ave.  Founder Mark Lee shut the promotion down when D.C. banned indoor smoking.

properties.Name: Lizard Lounge
properties.Notes: Gay male dance night at the Saint, Sundays.  Moved from 1520 14th St to 1223 Club on CT Ave.  Founder Mark Lee shut the promotion down when D.C. banned indoor smoking.

properties.Name: Mova
properties.Notes: Miami-based club reopened in a second DC location, replacing the P St location closed in 2010.

properties.Name: Mr. P's
properties.Notes: First gay club on the P St. strip. Patio behind the building. George Dotson and Gene Newsome first owners.  John Mako second owner.  Long tradition of drag shows.  Hostesses included Erica Kane, Xavier Bloomingdale, and Marilyn Monroe.  Upstairs bar called the Loft, Monday night leather crowd, Centaurs.

properties.Name: Omega
properties.Address: 2122 P St NW rear Washington DC
properties.Notes: The Fraternity House changed its name and décor to Omega.  The dance floor was removed.  After Cobalt burned (1998), Omega became the site of a Monday night drag show hosted by J C Van Raine. Popular Thursday night karaoke show.  Owner: Glenn Thompson.  Building sold at the end of 2012, shutting down the club.

properties.Name: Opera
properties.Notes: Popular dance club replaced Dakota

properties.Name: Secrets
properties.Notes: Behind Ziegfeld’s, featured nude dancers.  One of the businesses closed down by the city to build the Washington Nationals ballpark.  (See also entry for Ziegfeld’s.)

properties.Name: Sunday Mass
properties.Notes: Occasional early Sunday morning gay dance nights

properties.Name: Titan (Titan’s Ramrod)
properties.Notes: Upstairs bar above Hamburger Mary's/Dakota Cowgirl.  Used by BHT for annual grant awards and for fundraising events.  Briefly home to Ester Goldberg’s comedy revue after she left Chaos.  (See also entries for Dakota Cowgirl; Hamburger’s Mary’s.)

properties.Name: Wet
properties.Notes: Followed Lost & Found and Quorum at this location.  (See also entries for Edge; Lost & Found; Quorum; Zone.)

properties.Name: Windows
properties.Notes: Above Dupont Italian Kitchen restaurant; nicknamed "widows,” after its predominantly older crowd.  (See also entry for DIK Bar.)

properties.Name: Cage
properties.Notes: Gay night at Alchemy on Thursdays,

properties.Name: Club Fuego
properties.Notes: Hispanic gay Saturday dance night at Cada Vez restaurant.  The weekly Latino gay night started in 2003 at the Four Points Sheraton and moved to Cada Vez in 2005.  It was briefly at the Tequila Grill on K St NW.  Neighborhood and ANC pressed for reduced noise and hours, videotaped patrons entering and leaving in 2005.  Club first opened at the Four Points Sheraton (K & 12th NW) in January 2004, then moved to Tequila Grill (K & 20th NW) in June 2004.  Hosted Universo Latina drag pageant in April 2004.

properties.Name: Deco Cabana
properties.Notes: Latino club that followed Escandalo at this location, drag shows, popular late 90s.

properties.Name: 1409 Playbill Café
properties.Notes: Popular restaurant, featuring drag bingo and performance art

properties.Name: Apex
properties.Notes: In 2002, the owner of Badlands renamed the club Apex.  (See also entries for Badlands; Phase One of Dupont.)

properties.Name: Badlands
properties.Notes: Popular Dupont dance bar, managed by Sophie Tucker (Don Gilliken) for many years.   Home for many years of the Miss Capitol Pride pageant.  Accused of carding in the early 1980s.  Video bar, Annex, upstairs.  (See also entries for Apex; Phase One of Dupont.)

properties.Name: Black Cat
properties.Notes: Drew gay crowd on Saturday nights, lesbian shows late 90s.  Home of the popular women's program Mothertongue.

properties.Name: Chaos
properties.Notes: Replaced the short-lived Q Club.  Original owners:  Wes Sullivan, Carlos Aguilar. Chaos became a very diverse club with Latino, women's, and drag nights. Drag bingo (Tues), women’s night (Wed.) drag show (Sat), Latino drag (Fri.).  Hosted DC's only regularly scheduled drag kings show.  Among other show hosts have been Lena Lett, Leona Hemsley, Xavier Bloomingdale, Jordan Taylor, Gigi Couture, and Regina Joezet.

properties.Name: Dakota Cowgirl
properties.Notes: Popular 14th St restaurant, replaced Hamburger Mary’s at this location.  (See also entries for Hamburger Mary’s; Titan Bar.)

properties.Name: Excursions
properties.Notes: Monthly parties organized by Tony Vila, attract mixed gay/straight crowd

properties.Name: Fab Lounge
properties.Notes: Fab Lounge, located above a straight strip club, on the southeast corner of Florida and Connecticut Avenues, was delayed in opening by protests to the local ANC.

properties.Name: Franklyn's
properties.Notes: 18th St. coffeeshop with leather influence.  Regularly hosts fundraisers for the drag and leather communities

properties.Name: Halo
properties.Notes: Popular lounge on P St near 14th St.  First smoke-free lounge or bar in the gay community.  Halo attracts a youngish largely male crowd.  (See also entries for Mova.)

properties.Name: Hamburger Mary's
properties.Notes: Popular 14th St restaurant.  (See also entries for Dakota Cowgirl; Titan Bar.)

properties.Name: Hush
properties.Notes: Gay Thursday nights at Club Chloe

properties.Name: Sheridan's Dance Hall & Saloon
properties.Notes: Country & western restaurant and dance club.  Hosted drag bingo Wednesday nights and drag pageants.  Owner: Sandy Thompson

properties.Name: Town Danceboutique
properties.Notes: Major weekend-only dance club.  Features nightly drag performances.

properties.Name: Velvet Nation
properties.Address: S Capitol & K St SE Washington DC
properties.Notes: Saturday night gay night at the Nation nightclub.  Ed Bailey and John Guggenmos, producers.   Popular gay dance club closed due to development around a new baseball stadium site.

properties.Name: Zei Alley
properties.Notes: Club that hosted a variety of gay dance nights, including Atlas (and later Tantrum) on Friday nights.

properties.Name: Ziegfeld's
properties.Notes: Club that followed the Other Side at this location.  Backroom (Secrets) had nude male dancers.  Ziegfeld's hosted drag shows Thursday through Sunday.  Ella Fitzgerald hostess and show director.  Thursday nights were hosted by Sabrina White, Vita Opulence and others.  Owners: Chris Jansen, Allen Carroll.  Closed by eminent domain to use site for Washington Nationals ballpark.

properties.Name: Between Friends
properties.Notes: African-American-owned dance club, initially primarily a lesbian club.  Offered use of its space to community groups such as SMYAL, Mautner Project, and others.  Owners: Ibijinka Hicks, Addie Johnson, Tedara Lindsay, Vicki Harris.  The club ultimately closed in 2004 following problems with clubgoers.

properties.Name: Chocolate Bar
properties.Notes: A women's dance bar, Saturday's, organized by Loving People Like You, inc.

properties.Name: Ellington's on 8th
properties.Notes: Women's club on Sundays

properties.Name: Hung Jury
properties.Notes: One of the longest running women's bars in the city; dancing.

properties.Name: Phase One of Dupont
properties.Notes: Second location for Phase One (open simultaneously to Capitol Hill venue).  Took over the building that previously housed Apex and Badlands.  (See also entries for Apex; Badlands.)

properties.Name: Lammas
properties.Notes: Cultural center and bookstore for DC lesbian and feminist community.  Mary Farmer sold Lammas to Jane Troxell, Rosa Fennell, Marge Darling & Susan Fletcher in March 1993

properties.Name: Lammas
properties.Notes: Final location for Lammas.

properties.Name: Mova
properties.Notes: Halo converted to Mova under new management; rent and other financial disputes led to closing.  (See also entry for Halo.)

properties.Name: BeBar
properties.Notes: Opening of gay bar in Shaw neighborhood drew protests from African-American churches.  There were several incidents of anti-gay  violence associated with BeBar patrons.  Re-opened as the EFN Lounge.  Owner Michael Watson.  (See entry for EFN Lounge.)

properties.Name: Black Cat
properties.Notes: Frequent host for Mixtape and Gay/Bash! gay dance parties in new location, late 2000s.

properties.Name: Bohemian Caverns
properties.Notes: Bohemian Caverns, formerly Crystal Caverns, became a venue for occasional celebrations by African American social clubs such as the Best of Washington.  A short-lived drag cabaret in 2000 was succeeded by an African American gay dance night called Poison

properties.Name: EFN Lounge / Motley Bar
properties.Notes: Lounge that  replaced BeBar at this location.  “EFN Lounge” stood for “Edgy, Funky, Neighborhood Lounge.”  (See entry for BeBar.)

properties.Name: Lambda Literary Foundation
properties.Notes: Final location for LLF before takeover by board of directors moves the Foundation to New York City.

properties.Name: Nellie’s Sports Bar
properties.Notes: Popular multi-level gay sports bar.

properties.Name: Secrets
properties.Notes: Reopening of Secrets in new location.  In same complex as Ziegfeld’s.

properties.Name: Swim
properties.Notes: Sunday gay club night at Chloé in Adams Morgan

properties.Name: Ziegfeld’s
properties.Notes: Reopened in same complex as Secrets.  (See also entry for Secrets.)

properties.Name: The DC Center
properties.Notes: First office space for the newest incarnation of a LGBT community center, founded in December 2002.  (See also entries for Gay Community Center.)

properties.Name: The DC Center
properties.Notes: Temporary location for LGBT community center.

properties.Name: G Books
properties.Notes: Gay used book store, basement level.  Owner: Brandon Chan.

properties.Name: Whitman-Walker Clinic
properties.Notes: Changed named to Whitman-Walker Health in 2011.

properties.Name: Townhouse Tavern
properties.Notes: Local "dive-bar" in Dupont Circle;  site of a federal cocaine sting in 2011.
